comments: w is uniquely defined as the largest value such that for all n>0, a(n) is prime. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Oct 25 2006Hardy's paper uses this as an example, although the sequence is not well-defined there. The next term is probably 2^16382-35411, a 4932-digit prp. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Oct 25 2006
references: P. Ribenboim, Prime number records, Two-Year College Math. Jnl., 25 (1994), pp. 280-290.
E. M. Wright, A prime-representing function, American Mathematical Monthly, 58 (1951), pp. 616-618.
formula: a(0) = 1, a(n) = the greatest prime less than 2^(a(n-1)+1). - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Oct 25 2006
author: _Robert G. Wilson v_
